stories.text:
Hey HN!

If you haven't heard, Rhythm was given a cease and desist order. This made me think it would be really fun to learn how it worked, so I made an extremely minimal but viable solution in JS.

It's small, it works and it doesn't use your filesystem. Also note, I'm not encouraging that anyone use this.

All feedback and criticisms are welcome!

https://github.com/jessehorne/bop

p.s If you were YouTube or Rhythm, how would you have handled this situation differently? Could there be a way to keep bots like these without having them shut down and also without going bankrupt while running them?
stories.title: Show HN: A Discord Bot That Plays Music from YouTube (RIP Rhythm)

stories.text:
I just noticed linkedin is collecting demographic data. The copy says "Help promote fairness and diversity on LinkedIn by answering a few demographic questions." I'm not sure how they define fairness here or what their intent is.

Then it says "We’ll keep your responses confidential and secure." So what do they do with this data?

Digging into the learn more link shows

"We’ll use Self-ID data to:

Measure outcomes for different demographic groups on LinkedIn

Ensure our search results are fair and representative

Publish reports on workplace diversity trends

Help companies analyze their workforce composition, without revealing your name or personal information"
stories.title: Ask HN: Should Linkein be collecting demographic data?

stories.text:
I see all these posts about how much more privacy-focused the EU is vs the US, the GDPR, blah, blah, blah.

Yesterday I was going to check out the free 75GB trial of Scaleway's S3 service to see how it compared to others. However, it wouldn't let me create a bucket until I gave my credit card info, whereas Backblaze lets a free account use 10GB without giving any credit card. So I decided to pass on Scaleway.

I couldn't find the link to delete my account and had to use their online chat service. The link wasn't where they said it was, but I did poke around and find it. It was very clear that it was going to erase all data about me, referenced "data processors" and "data controllers", blah, blah, blah.

And since then I have received two emails from them encouraging me to try out their service, how to get started, etc.

So much for everyone in the EU having control of their data. Maybe it's because I'm in the US and their fancy, convoluted rules don't apply. Seems like any other company I've dealt with.
stories.title: Scaleway and Europe's big privacy focus
